Title: Bengaluru students forge their identities with the class sweatshirt
Content: College life is not only about academics and extra-curricular activities and making friends forever, it is just as much about being able to preserve those memories with memorabilia. While the college magazine is one such, what also takes a pride of place in the collection are the hoodies, sweatshirts, jackets or even caps that have the institution’s name and the year of the batch (and course stream) emblazoned on it. What makes these wearable items even more special is that the onus of designing them for the year falls on the students. A sweatshirt, then, is no longer just a piece of clothing; it is an extension of their identity and something to remember the time spent in class with friends by.Designing a class hoodie or a sweatshirt , though, is about more than just putting the college logo on it. It is quite the process, which involves weeks of brainstorming, before the entire class gets to wear the final product. “Designing the sweatshirt for the class is an activity we look forward to, especially when we are in our final year. It is usually an elaborate process, because the whole class is involved in this. There are multiple steps. Right from choosing the colour scheme, material, design, logistics and everything else, there is a lot of brainstorming,” says B Shreyas Padmanabha Sharma, a final year student at St. Joseph’s College (Autonomous). Nischay, a final year student of NITTE Meenakshi Institute of Technology, says that since everyone is involved in the process, it helps create memories as well. “We divide the class into different groups — one takes care of the design, one handles logistics and such. Working together on something like this actually brings us together,” he says.Since a lot of detailing goes into designing the sweatshirt, it also gives rise to a lot of arguments and discussions. “When we sit down to design the logo, we want it to represent who we are — the class we belong to or the clubs we are members of. Everyone comes up with an idea for the logo and reaching a consensus is a major task. Another challenge that we face is the choice of colour. It is very difficult to find one that everyone agrees on. So, usually the discussions spill over after class and on our social media groups too,” says Shreyas.For Sanjana Karanam, a 2nd- year student from RV College of Engineering, the club sweatshirt or t-shirt is what holds more value. “We do not have a class sweatshirt. Instead, we have various clubs on campus and each club has a sweatshirt or a t-shirt of its own. For example, I am a part of the RVQuizCorp — a quiz club — and we have designed our sweatshirt and t-shirt as well. For us, these are like an extension of our identity on campus. People recognise us as being part of these clubs when we wear these, especially during college fests,” says Sanjana. Aman Singh, another student from the same college, shows off his Hindi theatre group sweatshirt and explains, “Since we are into street plays and theatre, our club sweatshirt reads ‘Loud By Choice’. We designed the logo in such a way that it brings out the true essence of our club, which is why we have half face as part of the logo.”Assigning tasks during the process too is crucial. “We assign the tasks to students who we know can handle the job. For example, someone who is good at drawing and has a sense of visuals will take up designing the logo. Anyone with a business acumen is tasked with working out the cost with the vendor or buying the raw material in bulk,” says Rajat Keshri, a 2nd-year student from RV College of Engineering.Such is the sense of pride that a class sweatshirt evokes that it is not only the current batch of students, but alumni too who sport it every time they are back on campus. “Our recently concluded fest was attended by a lot of our alumni and they all wore their sweatshirts. It just goes to show how important the sweatshirt is, and makes it easy for them to spot batchmates and for us to find seniors in attendance,” says Sanjana.

Title: A grand homecoming for LIVA Miss Diva Universe 2020 Adline Castelino
Content:
Reliving memories, and creating new ones at Mangaluru

Discussing farmer’s issues with the CM

Path ahead: Adline wants to emulate Lara’s feat

For LIVA Miss Diva Universe 2020 Adline Castelino , the last few days have been nothing short of magical. After her win, she was welcomed back at home in Mangaluru and Udupi like a princess. From innumerable number of selfies to gorging on her favourite food while catching up with family, to the trip culminating with a pitstop in Bengaluru and a visit to meet the Chief Minister of Karnataka, Adline says that the memories will remain priceless.“It was a grand welcome back home, I’d never expected anything like this. People came in such large numbers to celebrate my victory. I got to spend time at home with my mum, who flew in from Kuwait after four years, just to be with me. I also got to spend time with my sister and all my relatives,” says Adline.She also tells us that this time around, she was able to visit a lot of her favourite places in Mangaluru, after a long time. She visited her family church as well as one of her favourite Krishna temples in Mangaluru. “I also got to savour a lot of my favourite things on this trip, which included gudbud , the ice cream that I’ve feasted on since I was a child. At home, we even had our traditional meal on banana leaf, and the best part about that was the payasam made by my mother,” she adds.“It has been a delightful experience to meet the Chief Minister BS Yediyurappa. It is an experience that I will cherish my entire life. I got the opportunity to speak to him about the issues that farmers face. It is a cause that he has extensively worked with and it is a cause I am passionate about, and am working towards. I am grateful that he took the time off to talk about this — because these issues really matter,” says Adline.Adline feels the work begins now. “We are going to start preparing for Miss Universe. It has been 20 years since Lara Dutta ma’am won the Miss Universe pageant. She is from Karnataka. And now, we have gotten the opportunity to bag the Miss Universe title again,” she says, adding, “There is a lot of work to be done and I am really excited about it. I hope to make my people, my state and my country proud.”

Title: Nazriya: I’m now clear on what kind of films I want to be part of
Content: Cute, bubbly, girl next door. No longer. That’s probably what Nazriya Nazim proved with her latest outing as the alcohol-swilling, weed-smoking Esther Lopez in Anwar Rasheed 's Trance . It was a breakaway from the roles that she is best known for in films such as Ohm Shanti Oshana and Bangalore Days. In a candid chat, the actress talks to us about her biggest worry playing Esther, working with husband Fahadh and if she misses the process of doing back-to-back films.Everything that you see onscreen. I think that’s what appealed to me to do this. And I haven’t played such a character before. So, there was that curiosity on how the role would turn out if I play it. I think that’s also one of the reasons why Anbukka (Anwar Rasheed) wanted me to do the role. Anbukka took the risk and it wasn’t easy for him. Frankly, it’s also the first time that someone has approached me to do a character like this. It’s not like I took a decision that I won’t play such roles.The time I was mostly active was during those two years, and back then I was really busy to entertain such thoughts. And there was so much love from the audience for my roles, and I didn’t go through that phase where I had to think about that.More than the character, it was her habits that I was more worried about. I wanted to get those right before we started shoot – be it smoking or drinking. I didn’t want to look like an actor who had no idea about these when she was playing a chain-smoker and an alcoholic. We had already decided on Esther’s look, so I had to get that right too. But apart from these, there weren’t any other preparations. Everything else was done on the set.Yes, at different points. Fahadh was involved in the film, much before I was approached to do a role. So, I was in the loop about the discussions and the story before I became part of the film. I always knew that feel of the movie and what they were trying to do with Trance, because obviously we live in the same house.I think he is. He is totally with the film till it is over. He works on his character every day even after coming home. Trance, especially, had a lot of dialogues including Bible verses and he was completely involved in it.Being an actor, it’s kind of an inspiration to be around him. His dedication and hard work for each and every film pushes me too. He has always been supportive. There has never been a discussion on whether I should or shouldn’t do films. There was a time after our wedding when I had lazy days and he would say, ‘You should listen to scripts. Entha madiyaayo?’Being there and seeing the process. It was unlike any other film I did. To be part of a movie with such great names, irrespective of the length of the character, was a big deal.I have been waiting for roles, that’s how I have worked.I do, sometimes. But I am very clear on what kind of films I want to do and what characters I want to play. I have that clarity now.The biggest change would be social media. It has become crazy now. There are so many ways to put out your film and promote it. It has become easier and better, but at the same time you must be careful. Anything happening behind the scenes comes out instantly. We are also at a good space and amazing content is being made.We were all aware that it had a sensitive subject. But we were very sure that we haven’t tried to hurt any faith in particular or we aren’t blaming everyone for these acts. We were trying to show something that was actually happening. We were ready to take that risk and go ahead.These movies are all baby steps for that (laughs). Let’s see when it happens.I realise that there has been a gap between my films only when people tell me that. That’s because we are either producing a film or listening to scripts. So, I have always thought that I have been part of cinema. Otherwise we are at home or we travel whenever we can.

Title: No songs, no fights in Vijay Suriya’s next film
Content: There’s nothing ‘formulaic’ about TV star turned film actor Vijay Suriya ’s next big screen outing. “It’s probably the state of mind that I am in right now that made me accept this film. The subject explores the life of an IT guy and the changes that he goes through with each significant situation in his life. Personally, from a singleton, to a married man last year, and turning father recently, I could relate to the metamorphosis of the protagonist’s life and that stayed with me,” shares Vijay, who amidst his TV outings has gone about shooting for an upcoming film. Made by a team of newcomers, all working full-time in the IT sector, the yet-untitled film is being directed by Chethan Shetty and is being filmed at an IT firm in Bellandur . “The highlight is that it is not your regular masala flick and steers clear of cliches, song, dance and fights. The screenplay is the movie’s biggest draw,” shares Vijay. But he has chosen to imbibe one mass element into this film. “The team had suggested another name for the character, but I asked if they could change it to Siddharth — my character’s name from Agnisakshi; as people instantly connect to it,” he tells us. “Besides, I also handle the camera at work sometimes, because I love exploring and learning about the technical aspects of filmmaking . And after a really long time, I feel creative satisfaction on the sets... I like the high it gives me,” he trails off.

Title: Arundhati Nag returns to Marathi cinema after 40 years
Content: In 1979, a young Arundhati Nag (then Arundhati Rao ), made her debut on the big screen with the Marathi film 22 June 1897. But it took 40 years for the veteran actress, a known name in the film and theatre circuit of the country, to return to Marathi cinema . The Padma Shri awardee will soon be seen in Mohit Takalkar ’s directorial debut, Medium Spicy, in a special appearance. Arundhati, who has acted in multiple languages and has been part of Hindi films like Dil Se and Paa as well, will play the role of Laxmi Tipnis in the Marathi film. “Coming back to Marathi cinema after 40 years feels good. It’s a complete circle and yet, I feel almost like starting afresh as a debutant. I have seen Mohit’s plays at Ranga Shankara , in Bengaluru, and during one of the shows, he sat next to me and asked. ‘Aru Akka, I am planning to direct a film soon. There’s a role I would like you to do. Would you be a part of it?’,” reminisces Arundhati, who is all praises for her co-actor Lalit Prabhakar . She adds, “The script and a character description was sent to me, but magic happened when I reached the set and read the lines with my co-actor, Lalit. I feel he suits the role to the T and transforms into his character effortlessly.”On his part, Mohit shares that the dynamic character of Laxmi could’ve only been pulled off by Arundhati. Mohit added, “I know her since the last 15-20 years and she is a multi-faceted performer. She willingly came on board and I am happy about that. Though she’s had a long break from Marathi cinema, Arundhati maintains a fluency in Marathi and the role was a cakewalk for her.”— With inputs from Mihir.Bhanage@timesgroup.com

Title: Educational institutions, corporate offices gear up to fight Coronavirus
Content:
Wash your hands frequently and thoroughly with an alcohol-based hand rub or with soap and water

Maintain social distance i.e., at least 1 metre (3 feet) distance between yourself and anyone who is coughing or sneezing. If you are too close, you can breathe in the droplets, including the COVID-19 virus if the person coughing, is infected.

Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth, as the virus can transfer to your eyes, nose or mouth and enter your body.

Maintain good respiratory hygiene i.e., cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when you cough or sneeze. Dispose the used tissue immediately.

Seek medical care early if you have fever and cough, and if you experience difficulty in breathing.

Avoid contact with people who are coughing or appear sick.

If you have chosen to wear a mask, cover mouth and nose and do not touch it once worn.

Use alcohol-based hand sanitisers frequently and on completion of travel, wash hands with soap and water.

Include vitamin C rich food like oranges, lemon, sweet lemon and guava

Banana and coconut water are rich in zinc and therefore help build immunity

Green leafy vegetables like spinach, methi, and locally grown leafy greens must be eaten 3-4 times a week

Seasonal fruits like strawberries and grapes along with fruits like papaya and pineapple must be included in the diet at all times

Ensure food, especially non vegetarian, is well-cooked

Almonds are rich in vitamin E and is a good anti-oxidant

Include seeds like chia and sesame seeds in your diet

Inputs by holistic health coach Preety Tyagi, and wellness consultant Sheela Krishnaswamy

Close on the heels of countries going on high alert because of the Coronavirus (COVID-19), Bengaluru too seems to be well on its toes when it comes to the prevention and spread of the virus. BT finds out how the city is gearing up to fight the fatal virus.In the wake of the coronavirus scare, city colleges are looking at cancelling all scheduled official trips for students and teachers for the time being. “We have created awareness among teachers and mentors who are keeping a close watch on students. There is a student’s trip to Ramanagara scheduled this week, but this will most likely be cancelled,” says Lekha George, professor, Department of Botany at Mount Carmel College. At St. Joseph’s College (Autonomous) has introduced soap dispensers and hand sanitisers in all the restrooms on campus. “We don’t want anyone to panic, we are disseminating correct information among students and the administration,” says Kiran Jeevan, the PRO for the college.With health experts stating that the COVID-19 will probably become endemic soon, corporate houses in Bengaluru are taking extra measures to ensure employee safety. “We had a workshop on everything that we need to know about coronavirus wherein medical experts were called in to impart the required information about the virus,” informs Sangeeta Bora, of Ness Digital Engineering. An employee from Siemens informs that, “We have received a Corona safety booklet from the company which tells us about the virus and how it is best to avoid crowds contact with people who seem to be ill.” Many companies (especially those within the vicinity of the company where Bengaluru’s first and lone case till now was reported) have asked employees to work from home.Companies like Capgemini and Western Digital confirm that their upcoming meetings that required them to travel have been put on hold for now. “We have not restricted our travel itinerary to all countries as of now, but we are avoiding travel to countries that have reported deaths and have an endemic-likesituation. We are looking at having our meetings over video calls instead,” explains Sangeeta Bora, of Ness Digital Engineering.With crucial annual exams scheduled to take place all this month, authorities at education boards inform that circulars on precautionary measures have been sent out to students, teachers and parents. “Students suffering from cold, cough and fever will need to wear masks at the examination hall. They may also be provided a separate space to write their exams. We are also working on appointing a nurse or a health official at the exam centers,” said V Sumangala, director of KarnatakaSecondary EducationExamination Board.

Title: Photos: Ananya Panday flashes her sweet smile as she at Versova jetty sans Vijay Deverakonda
Content: Tiger Shroff, who is one of the most loved actors in Bollywood, has taken to social media by storm with his debut single ‘Unbelievable’. He has now taken to his Instagram handle to thank his fans as his song is placed in the 2nd position on the Billboard global charts.

Title: A play with anti-war message staged in Lucknow
Content:
(L) A scene from the play (R) Dr Anil Rastogi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

(L) Laraib and Vijay Tiwari (R) Padma Gidwani (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Mamta Saxena and Sangam Bahuguna (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Swatantra Kale and Devendra Modi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

(L) Dr Urmil Kumar Thapliyal (R) Amit Dixit (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

A two-day docudrama with an anti-war message, Hey Brecht was staged at the auditorium of Sangeet Natak Akademi . The play was based on the German playwright and poet Bertolt Brecht and conveyed the message of no wars. It was written and directed by Dr Urmil Kumar Thapliyal .(L) A scene from the play (R) Dr Anil Rastogi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)The tragedy of war was narrated, showcasing the period of Hitler, the cruel German leader. In the play, the world’s shortest poem, Hum, Bomb, Khatam, was introduced. The drama performed brilliantly by Rosy Dubey, Nitish Bhardwaj , Archana Shukla, Ritun Thapliyal Mishra, Yuvraj Vikram Singh , Arpit Katiyar, Priyanshi Pal and Pankaj Satyarthi among others.— Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui(L) Laraib and Vijay Tiwari (R) Padma Gidwani (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Mamta Saxena and Sangam Bahuguna (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Swatantra Kale and Devendra Modi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L) Dr Urmil Kumar Thapliyal (R) Amit Dixit (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Title: bigg boss: I’d really wished to earn a name for myself in the industry with my stint in Bigg Boss: Arti Singh
Content:
Arti Singh offering prayers at Mankameshwar Temple (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Arti, who loves Lakhnawi chaat, feasted on it (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

She went shopping for Holi and bought chikan kurtas for herself (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)

Coming to Lucknow for the first time after her stint in Bigg Boss 13, actress Arti Singh made sure to complete all her mannats that she had wished for at temples in Lucknow before she entered the house. The Waaris serial fame actress on Tuesday went on a spiritual sojourn in the city. “I had really wished to earn a name for myself in the industry. This is what I had always asked lord Shiva for and so when my Bigg Boss journey ended, I made sure to take time out and come to Lucknow so that I can visit my favourite temple Mankameshwar,” said Arti, who also went to Deva Sharif Dargah on Monday.Arti Singh offering prayers at Mankameshwar Temple (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)She added, “I have been coming to this temple since childhood with my mom. I feel a certain connect with Lord Shiva and you know the best part is that mere solah somvar vrat got over inside the Bigg Boss house last month. What a coincidence! I will be coming again to do the shringar of Lord Shiva.”Later, Arti also went to the Hanuman Setu temple. “This Hanuman Setu temple visit was something my bhabhi had wished for me. She was praying for my success all this while when I was inside the Bigg Boss house. I am really blessed to have such a loving family,” smiled Arti.A complete foodie, the Parichay actress then went to have the famous basket chaat of Lucknow. “There is no doubt about this that I love eating good food. Aate hi maine apni bhabhi ke haath ka khana khaya. She really cooks well. I missed Lucknow ki chaat badly inside the house, and so I planned to come here to Hazratganj to eat the basket chaat. I know it is really heavy and is equivalent to one whole meal, but I just can't resist it. Honestly speaking, meri aatma taras gayi thi Lucknow ki chaat ke liye. In fact, jaise hi main Lucknow pahunchi, my family and friends teased me saying ki ab toh tu chaat khaane jayegi zaroor.”Wrapping up her trip to Luckow, Arti then went to a famous chikan shop in Hazratganj to purchase some colourful clothes for Holi. “I have a huge collection of chikan stuff in Mumbai. I really love wearing chikan clothes. So since I was here before Holi, I thought of taking some stuff for the Holi parties,” said she.Arti, who loves Lakhnawi chaat, feasted on it (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Ask Arti about her journey inside the Bigg Boss house and she says, “I am really happy with my Bigg Boss journey. My journey inside the reality show was full of ups and downs and it was because of me as I am an emotional person. At times I used to lose my patience and felt like running from the house. But then I used to calm myself down and think that getting hyper will not be of any help to me. Also, for me Bigg Boss was my last chance to prove myself in the industry. In the beginning of my journey, I lacked confidence, I also got a panic attack. And after that attack, I realized that now everything about me is revealed, what else is left for the viewers to watch. That attack motivated me and helped me get going ahead inside the house. Later, I knew that I was the best and no one can compete with me in the house.” She added, “The perception of people has changed after I came out of the Bigg Boss house. People, who thought that probably I am capable of doing nothing in life, now are proud of me. I am getting so much love from the people after the show.”The actress also says that she was very conscious of the image she portrayed while inside the house. “I was image-conscious inside the house. I restrained myself from getting into any sort of controversies. People had several misconceptions in their mind regarding me and Sidharth Shukla . They had already linked both of us together that ‘Arti Singh is dating Sidharth.’ So at that point, I did not give any clarifications and thought that people would eventually come to know about my relationship status with Shukla, and within two weeks it was clear that there is nothing between the two of us. I did not pay much heed to the controversies surrounding me. But yes I was image-conscious as I was under a lot of pressure when I entered the Bigg Boss house. I belong to a family of stars and my mother wants me to get married and if I had given in to controversies so who would agree to marry me?”She went shopping for Holi and bought chikan kurtas for herself (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Talking about her most memorable moments and worst ones inside the house, Arti said, “There is not one but three best memories of the house which I will cherish for life. The first was when everyone inside the house voted against me and then I was made the captain of the house. The second one which gave me a lot of strength inside the house was when Asim (Riaz) gave me a handwritten letter from my mother during a task giving away his option to become a captain. And last and not the least is when my brother Krushna Abhishek paid me a visit inside the house with the kids and later Kashmira also joined in. It really boosted my self-confidence.”Ask her if she thinks Sidharth deserved to be the winner and Arti says, “As far as I have seen, the craze of the people inside the house, everyone was in favour of Sidharth. Then slowly the craze shifted to Asim Riaz . After seeing the fondness of the people, even I thought that Sidharth will definitely emerge as the winner and for the female winner I had solid vibes that probably I might win the trophy. But, I really feel that since I was not declared the winner so I hardly care whether Sidharth won it or not. I knew he would win and may the best person win that was the situation at that time. And if I have not won then how do things matter to me.”Arti, who played her second innings with Bigg Boss, has been quite vocal about getting married. “There is no hurry to get married, but I feel that there is always a time when things should happen. I have never been an ambitious person in life and abhi I need to earn a name for myself and jab tak kaam chal raha hai chalega. But as far as marriage is concerned, I want to get married and enjoy my life for two-three years and then have kids. I don’t want to get married late. I have always felt there is a right age to get married,” she said.Talk to her about her upcoming projects she revealed, “Talks are on for a film project which was offered to me recently. Plus, I want to do television and definitely a dance reality show. I am fond of dancing so I would love to do a dance reality show. And as far as films are concerned, it should be strong in terms of the content and script which should appeal to me. Also I would love to do Khatron Ke Khiladi and I have decided to work on my strengths in order to do the show.- with inputs from Prachi Arya

Title: bigg boss: I’d really wished to earn a name for myself in the industry with my stint in Bigg Boss: Arti Singh
Content: Coming to Lucknow for the first time after her stint in Bigg Boss 13, actress Arti Singh made sure to complete all her mannats that she had wished for at temples in Lucknow before she entered the house. The Waaris serial fame actress on Tuesday went on a spiritual sojourn in the city. “I had really wished to earn a name for myself in the industry. This is what I had always asked lord Shiva for and so when my Bigg Boss journey ended, I made sure to take time out and come to Lucknow so that I can visit my favourite temple Mankameshwar,” said Arti, who also went to Deva Sharif Dargah on Monday.Arti Singh offering prayers at Mankameshwar Temple (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)She added, “I have been coming to this temple since childhood with my mom. I feel a certain connect with Lord Shiva and you know the best part is that mere solah somvar vrat got over inside the Bigg Boss house last month. What a coincidence! I will be coming again to do the shringar of Lord Shiva.”Later, Arti also went to the Hanuman Setu temple. “This Hanuman Setu temple visit was something my bhabhi had wished for me. She was praying for my success all this while when I was inside the Bigg Boss house. I am really blessed to have such a loving family,” smiled Arti.A complete foodie, the Parichay actress then went to have the famous basket chaat of Lucknow. “There is no doubt about this that I love eating good food. Aate hi maine apni bhabhi ke haath ka khana khaya. She really cooks well. I missed Lucknow ki chaat badly inside the house, and so I planned to come here to Hazratganj to eat the basket chaat. I know it is really heavy and is equivalent to one whole meal, but I just can't resist it. Honestly speaking, meri aatma taras gayi thi Lucknow ki chaat ke liye. In fact, jaise hi main Lucknow pahunchi, my family and friends teased me saying ki ab toh tu chaat khaane jayegi zaroor.”Wrapping up her trip to Luckow, Arti then went to a famous chikan shop in Hazratganj to purchase some colourful clothes for Holi. “I have a huge collection of chikan stuff in Mumbai. I really love wearing chikan clothes. So since I was here before Holi, I thought of taking some stuff for the Holi parties,” said she.Arti, who loves Lakhnawi chaat, feasted on it (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Ask Arti about her journey inside the Bigg Boss house and she says, “I am really happy with my Bigg Boss journey. My journey inside the reality show was full of ups and downs and it was because of me as I am an emotional person. At times I used to lose my patience and felt like running from the house. But then I used to calm myself down and think that getting hyper will not be of any help to me. Also, for me Bigg Boss was my last chance to prove myself in the industry. In the beginning of my journey, I lacked confidence, I also got a panic attack. And after that attack, I realized that now everything about me is revealed, what else is left for the viewers to watch. That attack motivated me and helped me get going ahead inside the house. Later, I knew that I was the best and no one can compete with me in the house.” She added, “The perception of people has changed after I came out of the Bigg Boss house. People, who thought that probably I am capable of doing nothing in life, now are proud of me. I am getting so much love from the people after the show.”The actress also says that she was very conscious of the image she portrayed while inside the house. “I was image-conscious inside the house. I restrained myself from getting into any sort of controversies. People had several misconceptions in their mind regarding me and Sidharth Shukla . They had already linked both of us together that ‘Arti Singh is dating Sidharth.’ So at that point, I did not give any clarifications and thought that people would eventually come to know about my relationship status with Shukla, and within two weeks it was clear that there is nothing between the two of us. I did not pay much heed to the controversies surrounding me. But yes I was image-conscious as I was under a lot of pressure when I entered the Bigg Boss house. I belong to a family of stars and my mother wants me to get married and if I had given in to controversies so who would agree to marry me?”She went shopping for Holi and bought chikan kurtas for herself (BCCL/ Vishnu Jaiswal)Talking about her most memorable moments and worst ones inside the house, Arti said, “There is not one but three best memories of the house which I will cherish for life. The first was when everyone inside the house voted against me and then I was made the captain of the house. The second one which gave me a lot of strength inside the house was when Asim (Riaz) gave me a handwritten letter from my mother during a task giving away his option to become a captain. And last and not the least is when my brother Krushna Abhishek paid me a visit inside the house with the kids and later Kashmira also joined in. It really boosted my self-confidence.”Ask her if she thinks Sidharth deserved to be the winner and Arti says, “As far as I have seen, the craze of the people inside the house, everyone was in favour of Sidharth. Then slowly the craze shifted to Asim Riaz . After seeing the fondness of the people, even I thought that Sidharth will definitely emerge as the winner and for the female winner I had solid vibes that probably I might win the trophy. But, I really feel that since I was not declared the winner so I hardly care whether Sidharth won it or not. I knew he would win and may the best person win that was the situation at that time. And if I have not won then how do things matter to me.”Arti, who played her second innings with Bigg Boss, has been quite vocal about getting married. “There is no hurry to get married, but I feel that there is always a time when things should happen. I have never been an ambitious person in life and abhi I need to earn a name for myself and jab tak kaam chal raha hai chalega. But as far as marriage is concerned, I want to get married and enjoy my life for two-three years and then have kids. I don’t want to get married late. I have always felt there is a right age to get married,” she said.Talk to her about her upcoming projects she revealed, “Talks are on for a film project which was offered to me recently. Plus, I want to do television and definitely a dance reality show. I am fond of dancing so I would love to do a dance reality show. And as far as films are concerned, it should be strong in terms of the content and script which should appeal to me. Also I would love to do Khatron Ke Khiladi and I have decided to work on my strengths in order to do the show.- with inputs from Prachi Arya

Title: J Krishnamurti: A picture-perfect insight into the life of J Krishnamurti
Content:
A glimpse of the exhibition (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

An exhibit at the event (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

(L) Dr Anubhuti (R) Harsha Vinay (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

(L) Janani Pratap (R) Mansi B (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

(L) Kumar Radhakrishnan and Dr Ranjan Bajaj (R) Neerupama Bhangar (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

(L) Priya Kumar and Ananya Jha (R) Shivani Thakur (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

(L) Simon Pratap (R) Aadya Ranjan and Shrejal Chakraborty (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

Ashmita Singh (L) & Shrestha (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

Giving insight into the life and teachings of noted thinker J Krishnamurti , a three-day event was recently organised. An ensemble of events were held to commemorate the 125th birth anniversary of the great philosopher at The Krishnamurti Study Centre, Rajghat, where he stayed during his annual visits to the city.A glimpse of the exhibition (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)The visitors had an experiential understanding of the spiritual teacher, pictorially as well through audible means, in an exhibition, titled, The First Step Is the Last Step, that was curated by Krishnamurti Foundation of India .An exhibit at the event (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)Apart from the life of J Krishnamurti, that was shown through photographs, his views on religion, relationship, fear and harmony could also be heard through audio recordings that were constantly played. “The exhibition was an opportunity for us to bring J Krishnamurti to people of Varanasi, who might not have heard about him yet may find his teachings relevant to their life. The 125th birth anniversary offered us this window to connect with the people of Varanasi,” said Kumar Radhakrishnan , Joint Director, Rajghat Education Centre.(L) Dr Anubhuti (R) Harsha Vinay (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)The event concluded with screening of three documentaries by Harsha Vinay, that depicted the ritual practises, involving mirror, along the Malabar Coast of India.(L) Janani Pratap (R) Mansi B (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)(L) Kumar Radhakrishnan and Dr Ranjan Bajaj (R) Neerupama Bhangar (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)(L) Priya Kumar and Ananya Jha (R) Shivani Thakur (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)(L) Simon Pratap (R) Aadya Ranjan and Shrejal Chakraborty (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)Ashmita Singh (L) & Shrestha (BCCL/ Unmesh Pandey)

Title: A play with anti-war message staged in Lucknow
Content: A two-day docudrama with an anti-war message, Hey Brecht was staged at the auditorium of Sangeet Natak Akademi . The play was based on the German playwright and poet Bertolt Brecht and conveyed the message of no wars. It was written and directed by Dr Urmil Kumar Thapliyal (L) A scene from the play (R) Dr Anil Rastogi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)The tragedy of war was narrated, showcasing the period of Hitler, the cruel German leader. In the play, the world’s shortest poem, Hum, Bomb, Khatam, was introduced. The drama performed brilliantly by Rosy Dubey, Nitish Bhardwaj , Archana Shukla, Ritun Thapliyal Mishra, Yuvraj Vikram Singh , Arpit Katiyar, Priyanshi Pal and Pankaj Satyarthi among others.— Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui(L) Laraib and Vijay Tiwari (R) Padma Gidwani (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Mamta Saxena and Sangam Bahuguna (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Swatantra Kale and Devendra Modi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L) Dr Urmil Kumar Thapliyal (R) Amit Dixit (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Title: A cultural extravaganza by millenials at this college in Lucknow
Content: Avadh Girls Degree College organised its four-day long annual sports and cultural fest at their campus. After the two-day long sports meet, the cultural fest, Nazrana-e-Avadh began with much zeal and fervour. The cultural gala was a unique mix of events including dance competition, nukkad natak , book cover making competition, collage making competition, etc.(L) Zahra Khan and Shachika Singh (R) Bhoopesh Rai (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)The cultural fest was inaugurated with the lighting of the lamp by chief guest Abhishek Prakash , District Magistrate, Lucknow along with his wife Vijaylaxmi The event witnessed a huge participation from different colleges. There was quite an entertaining and informative street play on the theme Humanity Should Be Our Race, Love Should Be Our Religion. Dr Upma Chaturvedi , Principal of the college, said, “The fest has been taking place in this college since 1975. This year almost 19 different colleges and universities took part in Nazrana-e-Avadh. Events these like offer discipline, enjoyment, teamwork, dedication, grooming and personality development.”— Yashi Agarwal(L) Ritu Tripathi and Mansi Jaiswal (R) Dimple Trivedi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L) Jaismeen Hain (R) Preeti and Ritu (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L) Kushi Yadav (R) Renu Parihaar and Suman Jena (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L) Priyanka Kumari and Sana Parveen (R) Surabhi Modi (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)Richa Amarnani (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L-R) Satakshi, Mariyam Khan and Umama Khan (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)(L) Vijaylakshmi Prakash and Dr Upma Chaturvedi (R) Vipra Srivastava (BCCL/ Aditya Yadav)

Title: A pre-wedding vacation for Richa Chadha and Ali Fazal
Content: We were the first to tell you that Richa Chadha and Ali Fazal will tie the knot in the third week of April. The court marriage will be followed by ceremonies in Mumbai and Delhi. We heard that the couple is busy finishing their work assignments before their big day. Ali left for Los Angeles last night for an international project and will be back in a week, after which he will be in Bengaluru to complete another shoot. Interestingly, Richa will also be shooting in the same city around that time, and the two are hoping to take off on a short pre-wedding holiday after wrapping up their shoots. A source revealed, “Ali and Richa are planning to visit Hampi as they will be shooting in Karnataka and want to take some time off before thewedding festivities begin.”The source added, “The couple is quite quirky and do not want aregular wedding reception, where people stand on a stage and clickpictures. It is not their thing. So, the venue in Mumbai is also going to be designed accordingly.”

Title: Kareena Kapoor Khan: You need to have a strong gut and be made of steel to survive for so long
Content: As she enters the third decade of her journey in Bollywood, she comes across as an actor who does not let success ride on her mind and failure sink her heart. Even when she’s not in couture, she’s the best-dressed woman in the room, who makes for a smart, on-point conversationalist. Kareena Kapoor Khan talks to BT about Angrezi Medium, what drives her movie choices today and how, over time, she has become a relaxed and calm actor. Excerpts:I agree that it’s a small role, but I’d never played something like this before. I was in London for two months with Saif (Ali Khan, husband) while he was shooting for Jawaani Jaaneman when this came my way. They needed about a fortnight of my time. It sounded like a cool film to be a part of. Also, who wants to miss a chance to work with such a fantastic cast. Most importantly, it was the greed to work with Irrfan that got me going instantly. The story draws parallels between Radhika Madan ’s relationship with Irrfan, and the one I share with Dimple Kapadia in the film, who is my mother. It subtly talks about the kind of equation parents and kids share. In the brief screen time I have, my character has a brilliant arc. I couldn’t have turned this down. I loved working with Irrfan, he’s such a delight. Radhika is fantastic, and I’ve been a huge fan of Deepak Dobriyal ’s work since Omkara (2006). He’s magical. These guys are on some other plane; you stop feeling like an actor when you see them work.Dimple aunty is close to my family, and she’s actually seen me grow up. It was an honour to work with her and play her daughter. She was spectacular to work with. The way we did some of the emotionally challenging scenes — they turned out to be among my career’s best shots. There’s a portion where she confronts me which was quite tricky to get right, but it went off so well. It takes a performer like her to make it that much more convincing. I think a director also has a lot to do with how two people play out scenes. He pushes them in a particular direction, like Homi did in our case. He had lived with this script for longer than us, and he was so sure of what he wanted.No, not really. Of course, we all invest a part of ourselves in the roles we play, but I would never compare my equation with Dimple aunty in the film with what I share with my mother. My mom is the centre of my sister Lolo’s ( Karisma Kapoor ) and my universe. Our world revolves around her. Today, being a mother, I know how important a mother is to a child’s being. Our role is not restricted to feeding and bathing the child. The effect a mother has on the mind of her child runs deep. If I don’t see Taimur for two days, I feel uneasy. Sometimes, I don’t take him along when I’m shooting outdoors in another city. When I come home, the way he hugs me says a lot. His father does a great job of looking after him when I’m away, but I can see it in his eyes that he has missed me. I know that it’s going to get difficult for me to stay away from him as he grows older and starts formal school. I still have a year before that happens. I’m happy that my next film Takht will be shot in Mumbai. Being able to be around Taimur plays a big part in the way I choose my work. I can’t leave him behind. I can’t be away from my kid for too long. Sometimes, even promotions for three to four days in other cities gets to me because he’s not around.Not at all! Saif and I have our independent relationships with Homi and Dinesh. Saif didn’t even come on the set when I was shooting for this film. In fact, when I told him about the offer, he just said that I should do it and that it sounds like a good role and a cool film. Saif is not someone who believes in telling me what I should do and what I shouldn’t. As long as we have our time as a family, he’s not interested in what I’m doing because he trusts that I will do the right thing. To this day, Saif has not even asked me how it was to work on this film. He just asked me, “Are you having fun? I said, ‘Yeah!” and he said, “Cool.” He does not get into the details, and we don’t talk about my career, anyway. Yes, we definitely discuss his career a lot. This has worked beautifully for us.It’s hard to believe, but there was no plan whatsoever to be seen as a glamourous woman, ever. It just happened! I started off with an unconventional love story and have always been that kind of an actress. Yes, now that it’s been 20 years, people are realising it. Early on in my career, I worked in films like Chameli (2003), Dev (2004) and Yuva (2004). Obviously, the commercial films were mounted bigger, and they registered better with the audience, so the image of a diva got associated with me. As an actor, I had always wanted to do different kinds of films and I chose the best of what was offered to me. Usually, no actress agrees or chooses to do the smaller part, but I was keen to do Angrezi Medium. A few months ago, I was also the central character in Good Newwz. It’s a conscious decision to find interesting things to do. Today, I’m a relaxed and calm actor. Experiences in this insular world of films teach you a lot. You need to have a strong gut and be made of steel to survive for so long and be able to take every bottle chucked at you. That is the reason I’ve lasted for 20 years, and hopefully, will last another 20.I’ve worked in many films that he has backed as a producer over these years, but not with him as a director. It’s been a huge gap. In these years, Karan has made such different kinds of films and has worked with so many different actors. Working together will be a rude shock for both of us. He has evolved as a filmmaker, and I’m a different actor from what I used to be when I had played Poo in Kabhi Khushi Kabhie Gham. Takht, which is being directed by Karan, will be a different and a special journey for us. Also, it’s a drama set in the Mughal era and we are entering into such a space for the first time. Neither of us has done this before. He will leave no stone unturned to make an absolute spectacle. We’ve locked certain looks for the initial part of the shoot. I’ll also go in for diction training. If I were to ask Karan what I should do as prep for the part, he will pull my leg and say, “Since when have you become this sort of an actor?”

Title: Top judges and politicians attend a grand wedding bash in Delhi
Content:
A touch of peach and pink: pagdis pagdis pagdis The ‘cutest family’: Selfie with Kejriwal a big hit: (L-R) Manish Sisodia, Arvind Kejriwal and Mukul Rohatgi Justice GS Sistani with his wife Honey; Kanchan and Gurmeet Singh Pasricha


(L-R) Justice Dipak Misra and Justice S Muralidhar (L-R) Natasha; Justice AK Sikri (L-R) BS Bassi; Justice TS Thakur (L-R) Anil Baijal; Alok Verma (L-R) Rajnath Singh; Ravi Shankar Prasad (L-R) Rajeev Shukla; Abhishek Singhvi (L-R) DN Patel and Najeeb Jung (L-R) Gurmehar Singh Sistani; MS Gill (L-R) Justice Vipin Sanghi with Justice Sanjay Kishan Kaul Montek Singh Ahluwalia and RS Jaura Pari Bagga and Rajinder Bagga It is not every day that you get to see the top judges of the Delhi High Court , the Supreme Court and former CJIs (Chief Justice of India) hanging out, remembering their college days and reminiscing about decades of association with each other. But this is what happened when Justice GS Sistani, the second most senior judge of Delhi High Court, hosted a lunch for his daughter’s wedding at his residence on Sunday.The wedding of Nayamat, who’s a lawyer, and Apar, a businessman, was a meticulously planned event. A staff member told us, “From the way the entrance will look to the flower decor, everything had been planned in detail. In the morning, we had welcomed the baraat, after which everyone came for the anand karaj. Most of the family members and a few close friends were present for the ceremony and the guests and other VIPs later joined for lunch.” When it came to the men’s, peach and pink seemed to rule the wedding. Natasha, the bride’s sister-in-law, admitted that it was all colour-coordinated. She said, “All those in peach colouredare from bride’s side and all those in pinkare from groom’s side.”Many senior judges present at the do said that they felt nostalgic meeting so many friends at the party. Justice AK Sikri, who was the second most senior judge in the Supreme Court when he retired last year, told us, “The Sistanis are the cutest family I know, whether it is Sistani, his wife Honey or their children. They are a loving family and value friendship a lot. We (GS Sistani and he) were colleagues in the High Court for around seven-eight years. Our friendship has blossomed over the years.”Defence Minister Rajnath Singh, who is also GS Sistani’s neighbour, came to wish the couple, and so did a few other ministers. However, the most talked-about guest was CM Arvind Kejriwal , who came with Deputy CM Manish Sisodia , and spent some time with former CJIs. Family members and guests surrounded the CM’s sofa, and everyone wanted to get a photo clicked with him.
