Police arrested him and lodged him at the Puducherry central prison.

Title: Drop additional queries in NPR, says Narayanasamy
Content:
Puducherry: Chief minister V Narayanasamy on Wednesday urged Union home minister Amit Shah to drop additional queries in the 2020 survey to prepare the National Population Register ( NPR ).

In a letter to Shah, Narayanasamy urged him to remove the queries on the date and place of birth of both parents of citizens, their last place of residence, passport number, Aadhaar identity and voter identity card numbers, drivers’ license number and mother tongue while undertaking the massive survey in June and July to prepare the NPR.

Narayanasamy pointed out that illiterate poor people living without basic facilities will not be able to furnish the date and place of their birth, while senior citizens and destitute people will face hardship to furnish the date and place of birth of their parents.

“Seeking information from senior citizens and destitute people on the date and place of birth of both parents regardless of whether they are alive or not is insignificant,” he said.

Pointing out that the states of Bihar, Kerala and West Bengal have opposed NPR with additional queries, Narayanasamy said a sense of fear and panic has gripped people over seeking more information in the 2020 NPR survey compared to the one drafted by the previous UPA government in 2010.

He said though it was said that people can voluntarily come forward to furnish information on additional queries without providing any evidence, the presence of additional queries in the questionnaire has created panic.

“Hence, the Union government must drop the additional queries in the 2020 survey and stick to the queries posed during the previous 2010 survey,” Narayanasamy urged Shah in the letter.

He said people have started feeling ‘tense and insecure’ fearing that the Union government will link NPR with the National Register of Citizens (NRC) after passing the Citizenship amendment act (CAA).

People have now started fearing that the Union government, based on the information collected during the NPR, will divide them based on their religion and will strip them of citizenship.

He pointed out that the 2010 survey included queries on demographic details of individuals, including name, relationship to head of household, father’s name, mother’s name, spouse’s name (if married), sex, date of birth, marital status, place of birth, nationality (as declared), present address of residence, duration of stay at present address, permanent residential address, occupation and educational qualification.

The 2010 survey did not include any unnecessary queries, he said.

Title: Malaika Arora looks bold and beautiful in this sheer black ensemble; Arjun Kapoor comments THIS on it!
Content: Ananya Panday and Shah Rukh Khan's daughter Suhana Khan dole out major friendship goals with their social media banter. Recently, Ananya took to her Instagram handle to share a picture from one of her photoshoots. The photo went viral on social media in no time. Fans were all praise for the click. But what caught our attention is her bestie Suhana's comment.

Title: ‘Maoist movement on wane in Gadchiroli, future uncertain’
Content:
After laying down arms last week, Vilas Kolha , former commander-in-chief of banned CPI ( Maoist ), shares with TOI how life is after surrender, why it’s getting increasingly difficult to regroup dalams, reconnect with villagers and start offensive against police

Gadchiroli: Vilas Kolha, the former commander-in-chief of the banned Communist Party of India (Maoist) who surrendered before Gadchiroli police last week, sees an uncertain future for the armed rebel movement. “It has suffered unprecedented setback in Maharashtra,” he told TOI.Kolha, who has 147 offences against him including 22 murders and several encounters with police, says due to police presence it is no longer easy to camp in forests for more than a few hours and organize meetings in villages. “The party seniors goad us to regroup the dalams, revive the village base by getting close to people and execute some reverses on the police but now it’s a tough ask,” he says.Youngsters are no longer “coming to us”, according to Kolha, now 44 years old. “Unlike in the past, there is no support from villagers as police are winning them over some or the other way,” he says.Kolha became the first cadre of any rank from Maharashtra to have surrendered with an AK 47 and ammunitions. He spent 10 days in the forests, many times without food and sleep, before reaching the police. After fleeing a camp at Abhujmadh with an AK 47, Kolha said he had to hide the weapon in a nullah to avoid getting caught or killed by both Maoists and police.“I still dream of being in forest camps with my men and weapons. I then wake up abruptly and start trying to grab my AK-47, only to realize that I have surrendered,” says Kolha.Kolha joined the Maoists in 2000 after his mother was labelled a witch following which the family faced social ostracization. According to him, the original Maoist idea was to strengthen the mass base in forest and then head towards urban areas. “We had managed to put some organizations and cadres in cities too but most got arrested. Don’t know what will be the future from here on,” he says.According to him, around 200 of them were carrying the movement ahead in Gadchiroli. The number got depleted when 40 got killed in one go in the Kasnasur-Boriya twin encounters in April 2018.“Camping on the riverbank (Indravati river dividing Maharashtra and Chhattisgarh) was suicidal. We did not keep any escape route and so when the attack took place (from security forces), our cadres had no option but to jump in the river and die after getting surrounded,” he says adding that Maoists analyse each and every encounter or incident, irrespective of the consequences, to evolve best practices.“There were none to marshal the force after senior leaders like Sainath and Shreenu (divisional committee members or DVCM) were hit,” he says.The former dreaded Maoist, however, chose not to speak on the questionable encounter of DVCM Nandu and five others in Boriya on April 23, 2018, on the following day of Kasnasur fire exchange where 34 cadres were killed.Kolha was part of the team that orchestrated the Jambhulkheda blast. He clarified that it was neither revenge for Bhaskar’s wife Ramko’s (neutralized in questionable manner with her aide Shilpa at Gundurvahi in 2019) nor Kasnasur-Boriya encounters.He admits that the Kasnasur-Boriya encounters further shook up the already quivering mass base of Maoists in Gadchiroli. “The Jambhulkheda blast, in which 15 jawans died, happened last year after seniors started goading us to counter police to boost the movement’s morale,” he says.“We had to do something. Our team was more alert than the cops. We recovered two AK 47s and couple of SLRs from the site, rest were blown up,” adds Kolha.He stresses that Maoists get their supply of arms and weapons from the raids and operations against police and other forces, and nothing is procured. “We are told to use the ammunitions cautiously and not to waste them. The seniors question us if there is wastage,” says Kolha. He was trained using AKs, SLR and other weapons in the forest of Maoist headquarters of Abhujmadh.Kolha now wants to shift his wife from his native Vikaspalli to police headquarters where he is living under armed security protection. “After marriage, I left her in the house to join the dalam. She would always question me due to her loneliness and I would console her. Now, I will try to convince her to be at my side,” said Kolha who dreams to start a family despite knowing his life is under high risk and death can come even with a slightest of mistake.

Title: Mastermind of blast that killed 15 QRT jawans held
Content:
Gadchiroli: Dinkar Gota, one of the key masterminds of Dadapur arson and the Jambhulkheda blast later that claimed the lives of 15 jawans and one civilian driver in May last year, was arrested along with his wife Sunanda from the outskirts of Gadchiroli on Wednesday. The National Investigation Agency (NIA) may seek Gota’s custody in near future for the probe into the Jambhulkheda blast case.

The couple had Rs18 lakh reward on them announced by the Maharashtra state. Some 36 vehicles had been torched by the Maoists at Dadapur in Kurkheda on May 1 last year, before they triggered the blast at Jambhulkheda when cops were heading to investigate the arson in a private vehicle. The Quick Response Team (QRT) was heading to Purada police station when their vehicle was blown up.

Gota, having 108 offences against him including 33 murders, was the Divisional Committee Member (DVCM) of north Gadchiroli division working with the Korchi dalam. The planning and execution of Dadapur arson and Jambhulkheda blast was done by Gota, his fellow DVCM Bhaskar Hichami and another company 4 top cadre Satish. Hichami and Satish are still absconding.

SP Shailesh Balkawade said Gadchiroli police have several offences to be probed against Gota but NIA may also start the process to get his custody in coming days. “NIA has already chargesheeted eight accused in Jambhulkheda blast case, and they may seek his custody too through legal process available to them,” he said.

Gota’s second wife Sunanda Koreti, working as member of Korchi dalaan, has 38 offences against her.

It’s learnt Gota had fallen out with senior cadres for his extra-marital affairs. He was seriously warned and also asked to improve his behaviour. The party had already started an inquiry against him and was likely to suspend him, which had prompted him to desert the group with Sunanda in September last year.

Sources stated Gota’s first wife Sunita, working with Tippagarh dalam, had surrendered last year after he grew close to Sunanda. It was after this that party seniors issued a strict warning to Gota to dissociate from Sunanda, which he did not like.

Balkawade said there was a strong rumour about Gota being bumped off by his own party men. “We were after him since he left the party. The arrest of Gota and his wife was the cumulative effort of the intelligence unit, technical cell and the Special Investigation Team (SIT) we formed last year after the Jambhulkheda blast,” he said.

Sources from Gadchiroli police said Gota and Sunanda were staying incognito in a village near the police headquarters. They felt no one would search for a senior cadre like him in or around the town. They were somehow eking out a living, and their use of mobile phones led the cops to them.

Balkawade said separate offences were registered for Dadapur arson and Jambhulkheda blast. “We have arrested Gota and Sunanda in the Dadapur arson case and took custody remand of 14 days from court,” he said.

Balkawade also added that now NIA may transfer Gota in the Jambhulkheda case too. “We had registered a case against almost 100 cadres of Maoists for the Dadapur arson,” he said.

In a separate action, also in the early hours of Wednesday, Gadchiroli police team busted a Maoist camp at Khobramenda forest in the northern side of the district. Around 70-80 Maoists were attending the camp when C-60 commandos stormed the place. The cadres managed to flee but police recovered substantial materials like mines, explosives and literature. Search operation is still underway.

After the arrests of Gota, and surrender of Maoists’ former commander-in-chief Vilas Kolha last week, the north Gadchiroli command is now with Hichami. “Twice Hichami had miraculous escapes in our firing. If he does not surrender immediately, he may not see 2021,” said Balkawade.

HOW JAMBHULKHEDA BLAST TOOK PLACE

1. Around 400-500 Maoists cadres, including more than 100 women, raided the Dadapur village in Kurkheda taluka in north Gadchiroli shortly after midnight of April 30, 2019, and torched 36 vehicles of a road construction company eill early morning on May 1 (4.30am)

2. Maoists left banners at Dadapur village condemning encounters at Kasnasur-Boriya that had killed 40 cadres

3. A Naxal action team, expert in explosions and blasts, was deployed in an ambush at Lendhari nullah near Jambhulkheda village in anticipation police would cross the spot on way to Dadapur village to investigate the arson

4. The then SDPO Shailesh Kale walked into the trap by ordering his Quick Response Team (QRT) to reach Dadapur at 9.30am

5. The 15-member QRT team left Kurkheda police post at 9.30am in a private vehicle driven by a civilian

6. Maoists triggered blast to blow up entire squad and the driver on small bridge over Lendhari nullah

7. Gadchiroli police arrested eight persons, including senior-most cadres like Narmada and her husband Kiran, before probe was handed over to NIA

Title: Koka sanctuary gears up to tackle forest fires
Content:
Nagpur: Even as the forest fire season has onset, the WWF-India and Navegaon-Nagzira Tiger Reserve (NNTR) collaboratively organized a sensitization program on prevention of forest fire for villages around the Koka Wildlife Sanctuary.

The 100sqkm Koka sanctuary, which has several villages around it, is vulnerable to forest fires. Last year, over 50-hectare forest was burned in Koka.

Forest fire is a major issue in Maharashtra. According to information received under RTI, more than 4 lakh hectares of forest has been reduced to ashes in the last 10 years in the state.

Hence, NNTR and WWF-India organized a sensitization program on prevention of forest fire at Koka. Range forest officer (RFO) Sachin Jadhav has chalked out proactive measures to prevent forest fire this year.

Jadhav urged WWF-India’s Nagpur office to organize an awareness program on prevention of forest fire in villages where eco-development committees (EDCs) have been set up.

The program was organized in eight sensitive villages and two schools under the Koka range. Those who participated included senior citizens, youths and children.

Ajinkya Bhatkar, senior project officer, WWF-India, addressed villagers through a power point presentation and videos. He highlighted the fire in Amazon and Australia which impacted the entire world.

Bhatkar explained how forest fires impact the ecosystem. He urged people to make others aware about preventive measures to avoid forest fires and protect forests.

“A national movement needs to be launched to against forest fires. The forest department needs to be strengthened for firefighting. Without participation and the support of villagers, it is very difficult to save forests,” Bhatkar said.

The program was organized under the guidance of Poonam Pate, deputy director of NNTR. Round officers Rajendra Dhanvij and JG Nagpure and others coordinated with villagers.

Pate said, “During the tendu season, many fires are intentional. Forest fires don’t just destrpy trees. They kill and displace wildlife, alter water cycles and soil fertility and endanger the lives and livelihoods of local communities.”

Title: Three districts affected due to NMRDA’s apathy towards sewage treatment: Fuke
Content:
Through calling attention motion in Legislative Council during ongoing budget session in Mumbai on Thursday, M... Read More

Nagpur: MLC Parinay Fuke has alleged three districts— Nagpur, Bhandara and Gondia — Wainganga river and Gosikhurd dam are affected due to delay by Nagpur Metropolitan Region Development Authority ( NMRDA ) in preparing action plan to treat and reuse entire sewage generated from rural parts of Nagpur district.

Through calling attention motion in Legislative Council during ongoing budget session in Mumbai on Thursday, Fuke, a former guardian minister of Bhandara and Gondia, requested environment minister Aditya Thackeray to do the needful. Thackeray assured to resolve the problems.

Fuke said, “Three districts are affected to a great extent due to high-level pollution in Wainganga river and Gosikhurd dam. Always the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) is blamed for polluting these water bodies. NMC is treating 330 of total 500 million litres per day (MLD) and one more sewage treatment plant (STP) of 150 MLD is in the pipeline.

“Over 400 MLD sewage is generated from villages and towns situated in rural parts of Nagpur district. Not a single drop of sewage is being treated in these parts. In 2016, I had directed NMRDA, which is authority for rural parts of the district, to prepare an action plan to develop mini STPs and ensure zero discharge. It would have made huge difference. Even, former CM Devendra Fadnavis had directed NMRDA to prepare action plan. But NMRDA has done nothing in last four years,” he said.

Title: IBM marks 73rd foundation day
Content:
Nagpur: The Indian Bureau Mines ( IBM ) that has its headquarters in the city marked its 73rd foundation day this week.

Rajya Sabha member Dr Vikas Mahatme who was the chief guest on the occasion said mining is crucial for economic growth and complimented IBM for rendering its service in managing the country’s mineral wealth. He stressed that along with mining the endeavour should be to preserve the nature too.

Anupam Agnihotri, director, Jawaharlal Nehru Aluminium Research and Development Centre (JNARDC), spoke about the need for concentrating on 4Cs — Change, Creative, Courage & Connect.

Indira Ravindran, the controller general of IBM, spoke about the initiatives taken by the organization in various technological fronts in its endeavour to govern the mining and mineral development activities in the country, said a press release issued by the IBM.

IBM is a regulator of mining activities. It approves the mining plans and deals in other related issues for all minerals, except coal, and is responsible for ensuring compliance of laws by the mining entities.

Title: NU now says exam data of some colleges was lost
Content:
Nagpur: After initially denying any data loss, Nagpur University (NU) has admitted the summer exam forms of students submitted online by colleges were deleted from the server maintained by private agency Promarc Private Ltd.

Acting Pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande told TOI, “the reference number of some five to six colleges was not generated which led to the exam section calling for details from colleges again. There was no data loss as it was preserved at several other places when the problem occured at one server. The summer exam has commenced and all admit cards and other formalities have been initiated smoothly,” he said.

Deshpande said he had called for details from the agency. The reference number is important to ascertain number of students and their colleges.

Though the acting Pro-VC reiterated there was no data loss and the glitch was restricted to only some colleges, the revelation that there was a problem in reference number indicates there has been something amiss with the exam forms.

On Wednesday, TOI spoke to a couple of colleges from city, Bhandara, and Gondia, they confirmed they had to resubmit sumer exam forms online. Some colleges had submitted hard copies from which the exam section made online entries on its own. They also said the problem had been encountered at all the 503 affiliated colleges without exception.

The bungle came to fore when the exam section forwarded a checklist around mid-January to cross check name of students, their colleges and courses. However, several names were missing.

On Jan 30, TOI was the first to report about the big data loss. Several Senate members representing the students and teachers said they too were aware of the bungle that was cleverly kept under wraps by exam section. They have placed questions about this event which is likely to be discussed during the Friday’s senate meeting.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: What state did to prevent panic
Content:
Airport screening

Local intervention

Awareness drive

Infection protocol

Double check

Rumour-Busting

Border checks

KOCHI: In the beginning of February, Kerala had the first and only three confirmed cases of Covid-19 in India – three medical students who had returned from Wuhan in China, the epicentre of the disease. In less than a month, all three patients were treated successfully and discharged, as mandated, from isolation wards after testing negative twice in succession.Kerala has since been able to contain the spread of the virus through proactive protocols that seek to educate the general public about precautions to be taken without sounding unduly alarmist. Apart from carrying out a focused awareness campaign, the authorities have been quick to crack down on those spreading rumours about the outbreak.From immigration officials and police to panchayats and local-level health volunteers, a multi-tiered and seamlessly integrated system is in place. The following are some of the preventive measures initiated by the state government at the height of the coronavirus scare.Passengers arriving from abroad would be given a health card each in which they had to list their travel details and health condition. Before proceeding to immigration, they would need to get the details checked and stamped at a special desk. For passengers from China, Hong Kong or other coronavirus-affected regions, the protocol is to shift them to a transit room where their body temperature is immediately measured.Each of Kerala's five airports is linked to ambulance and emergency-response services in district hospitals. Any passenger who has fever, cough or sore throat is to be immediately shifted to the linked hospital and from there a message would be passed to the district medical office. This office immediately contacts the family members of the person and informs them about the isolation of the passenger. If the travellers have no symptoms, they are allowed to go home, subject to strict external surveillance by a health team.Immediately after the first case was detected, panchayat-level bodies across the state were issued a directive on infection-control and home isolation protocols. In a circular issued by the local self-government department, all local bodies were directed to prepare a list of people coming from places affected by the virus and of those in contact with such people. Multiple helplines were set up.The campaign focuses on basic hand and respiratory hygiene, including using a tissue or a flexed elbow to cover one's nose and mouth while coughing or sneezing. People have been advised to avoid handshakes and close contact with anyone suspected to have been infected. Standard prevention protocol also includes use of personal protective equipment, depending on riskAll private medical institutions, labs and consulting centres have been asked to strictly adhere to the recommended infection protocol. Around 215 mental health teams have reached out to 2,600 people in home quarantine to alleviate anxiety and also to counsel family members and people in the neighbourhood.Use of breathalysers has been temporarily suspended. Police personnel have been directed to use other methods such as medical examination to detect drink driving.Blood banks in all districts have implemented a mandatory precautionary measure to prevent transmission of the virus. They have commenced double screening of donors and stopped collecting blood samples from people who have recently arrived from abroad or those with a history of travel to foreign countries. A directive has been issued to all blood-donor forums, groups and NGOs that conduct blood-donation camps to double check the travel history of donors before referring them.District police chiefs have already initiated strict action against those found circulating fake news relating to the virus outbreak on social media.A team comprising doctors and other health care staff has been screening travellers entering Kerala by road. They use non-contact infrared thermometers to check body temperature and distribute pamphlets about precautions to be taken against Covid-19.

Title: A yr on, NU restarts process to fill up 22 LIT teaching posts
Content:
Nagpur: More than a year after conducting recruitment drive for it, the Nagpur University (NU) is again initiating the process to fill up 22 vacant teaching posts at its premier institution, Laxminarayan Institute of Technology ( LIT ).

The posts lying vacant for several years now has stalled the process for grant of autonomy to LIT. The institute has been struggling to offer itself for a National Board of Accreditation (NBA) and NAAC assessments for the last few years because of shortage of teachers.

“Without the assessments, the NU can’t apply for autonomy,” said acting pro-VC Vinayak Deshpande.

In 2018, vice-chancellor SP Kane had also submitted a proposal for grant of deemed university status to LIT with the Union HRD ministry.

The latest measure came following directives from the Nagpur bench of Bombay high court which ordered the VC and pro-VC to discuss the issue with the secretary of higher education and prepare a plan for removing the deficiencies by March 30.

Led by the secretary, a committee comprising VC, pro-VC, director (higher education) and director (technical education) has been asked to frame modalities, set a timeline and decide how it will be done.

Last week, the VC, pro-VC and LIT director Raju Mankar met higher education secretary Saurabh Vijay in Mumbai, following which the NU authorities started preparing a fresh proposal. “We are seeking 22 posts,” Deshpande said.

There are indications of a change in the roster. In a series of reports last year, TOI had highlighted staff imbalance at LIT.

During the 2019 recruitment drive, the NU had overlooked the staffing imbalance and advertised posts with hardly any workload. Lack of teachers for core subjects were ignored which ultimately made LIT again ineligible for NBA despite filling up 11 out of the 17 posts.

As per the old roster, the institute has 62 sanctoined teaching posts. A recent GR of technical education has also mandated 1:20 teacher-student ratio as per AICTE norms. This could also be another reason for modifying the roster.

Officials said as per government policy, only 80% of the teaching posts sought are approved like the last time when NU had sought around 29, but was given only 17. “This time, since it is being done in response to the HC order, LIT may get more posts,” they said.

Lack of qualified applicants too is a major challenge before NU to fulfil the dream of making LIT autonomous institution. For a long time, there were no applications for chemical technology specialization such as petrochemical, paper pulp, surface coating and oil technology.

The six posts that didn’t find any takers last time are from chemical technology. Professor and associate professor level posts are vacant which makes it more difficult to find a suitable candidate. Those possessing the requisite experience for these posts are generally well settled and need a strong reason to come to Nagpur, say insiders.

Title: Corporator Syeda Khatun disqualified over invalid caste certificate
Content:
Nagpur: The Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Wednesday disqualified city corporator Syeda Khatun upholding the claim of petitioner Kamil Ansari who had challenged validity of the OBC caste certificate submitted by her. This decision by the bench headed by Justices RK Deshpande and AB Borkar now means the seat held by Khatu, Ward No 8-B, is to be considered vacant.

Polls for Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) were held in 2017 and Khatun was declared winner from 8-B seat which was reserved for OBC candidate. Petitioner Ansari had then claimed her caste certificate was invalid and filed a complaint with Election Commission of India (ECI).

The certificate was put before a scrutiny committee that upheld it. Ansari then approached the court through his lawyer Narayan Phadnis. Phadnis argued the certificate issued in 2011 by district deputy collector was not valid and was in fact a non-creamy layer certificate. Phadnis said Khatun had claimed her OBC status under Jullaha community (weaver), but the documentation was not in order.

Jemini Kasat, counsel for NMC and ECI, said the deputy collector had mentioned in an affidavit the certificate issued on June 8, 2011 only pertained to non-creamy layer status. The court held that respondent had failed to bring on record any caste certificate.

Title: "My daughter doesn't want to eat! Please help."
Content: My 10 year old daughter was a healthy eater till the age of 5 years. But for the past 8-9 months she has undergone a strange transformation. She doesn’t want to eat anything. I have taken her to nutritionists but they say she will eat when she is hungry but that never happens. She is losing weight and I don’t know if I should seek professional help. Can you guide me?There may be a number of reasons as to why there has been a change in her eating pattern. If you have already consulted a medical professional, it would be beneficial to also get her Blood thyroid and LFT ( liver function tests) tests done. Ascertain whether her health parameters are growing in accordance with age. Enquire if any external stressors may be resulting in her feeling anxious or low and thus a loss of appetite. Also try to keep the home environment relatively stress free. What we also need to remember is to not obsess about food and not make it the sole focus of all conversations. It may be helpful to negotiate with her and make a food chart that involves a healthy diet as well as items that she is fond of. Positively reinforce healthy eating habits. It is important to note if there are any other significant behavioural changes or concerns relating to body image that have surfaced in the past few months. At times underlying stress can also manifest in this manner. In that case it is best to seek professional help.

Title: Two more test positive for Covid-19 in Hyderabad
Content: HYDERABAD: Two days after a 24-year software professional was confirmed as the first case of Covid-19 in Hyderabad, two more suspected cases tested positive in the first round of testing at the ICMR laboratory at Gandhi Medical College in Secunderabad. The samples have been sent to the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune for final confirmation.State health authorities also said that the first Covid-19 positive patient is stable even as 39 more people with initial symptoms were isolated at Gandhi Hospital and Fever Hospital on Wednesday. Another 55 people, who approached authorities for tests, were advised to quarantine themselves at home for 14 days.The two new cases whose samples have been sent to NIV include a software professional working at Raheja Mindspace in the IT hub and had visited Italy recently. The other is a sanitation worker at Apollo Hospitals at Secunderabad where the first positive patient had been treated initially“The NIV report is expected on Thursday,” said the Dr G Srinivas Rao, Telangana director public health. “The two patients are being kept in isolation at Gandhi Hospital. 45 others who tested negative were discharged and advised strict home isolation for 14 days.” On Wednesday, health minister Eatela Rajender asked IT professionals and others not to panic.

Title: Yami Gautam gets "caught in candid" and we can't stop gushing over her million-dollar smile in the picture
Content: From the High Court granting Rhea Chakraborty bail to Deepika Padukone gearing up to resume the shoot of Shakun Batra's next, here are all the top headlines of the day. Our new segment Bolly Buzz goes beyond the usual mix of news and gossip to give all its readers a roundup of all the newsmakers of the day.

Title: Beau Shawn Mendes throws Camila Cabello surprise Cinderella-themed bash
Content: American-Canadian singer Camila Cabello celebrated her birthday along with beau Shawn Mendes , who threw a surprise Cinderella-themed birthday party for her.According to a report, the 23-year-old singer is currently overseas in the United Kingdom filming for the upcoming musical remake of 'Cinderella' but that didn't stop Shawn Mendes from hopping on a plane and surprising his girlfriend with the best birthday celebration.Cabello was also joined by the rest of the 'Cinderella' cast. The director of the film Kay Cannon shared an adorable picture from the birthday party where the two can be seen smiling. Cannon also wished Cabello happy birthday in an Instagram post, the caption to the post reads, Sweet @camila_cabello turns 23 today!!! Celebratin' "Cinderella" style. Happy bday, Cinders!!!!! @shawnmendes."Irish actor Fra Fee also shared the pictures from the birthday bash. The actor shared a selfie of himself with the couple on Instagram, which shows Cabello blowing out the candles to her extravagant cake that was in the shape of Cinderella's carriage. The party also had with an ice sculpture in the shape of Cinderella's infamous glass slipper and it read, "Happy Birthday Camila."Fee captioned the post as, "HAPPY BIRTHDAY to the bloody beautiful legend @camila_cabello ... 23 today ... I mean... these kids."The actor also posted Instagram stories to post a video of the moment that Cabello walked into her surprise birthday party, alongside Mendes. While everyone sang "Happy Birthday", the birthday girl was jumping up and down.American actor Maddie Baillio also shared videos and pictures of Cabello, Mendes and everyone else celebrating the birthday girl. In one video posted on her Instagram stories, the Cabello and Mendes can be seen cutting the Cinderella carriage cake together.In one video posted to her Instagram Stories, the couple can be seen cutting the Cinderella carriage cake together and the ' Senorita ' singer can be seen opening up one of her birthday presents as well.The 'Shameless' singer also took some time out of her birthday to urge her followers to donate to Save the Children Fund in an Instagram post. The organisation established to improve the lives of children through education, health care and economic opportunities.The 'My Oh My' singer also took some time out of her birthday to urge her followers to donate to Save the Children Fund, an organization established to improve the lives of children through education, health care and economic opportunities.

Title: Keep clients away from courts, Telangana HC tells lawyers
Content: HYDERABAD: The Telangana high court took steps on Wednesday to clean its premises and told the state and its administrative machinery to leave no stone unturned to tackle the novel coronavirus (Covid-19).Chief justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan gave instructions through the registrar general to all the trial courts to not punish accused or jail authorities if the latter fail to produce accused before the court keeping in mind the HC’s appeal to lawyers to tell their clients not to come to court.“It is better to avoid gatherings of people. I am appealing to all lawyers to tell their clients not to come to courts, both the HC and trial courts,” the CJ said. “All jails must have quarantine facilities...,” he said.The CJ told advocate general B S Prasad in the morning that some doctors should be present in court from Thursday to screen all those who enter the high court premises and also to provide masks to all of them.He said some doctors should be deputed to screen those entering the court halls.The CJ also accorded permission to hear an urgent petition filed by G Siddha Lakshmi from Manikonda, in Hyderabad, seeking immediate steps to prevent the spread of Covid-19 by discouraging the celebration of Holi on March 9 and 10. A bench comprising the CJ and Justice Abhishek Reddy took up this PIL in the afternoon and directed the state to come out with a plan by Thursday to deal with the situation.Since slums are more vulnerable, the authorities must concentrate on them, the chief justice said. He also directed the DGP to review all permissions given by the police for huge public meetings in view of the emerging situation. And this is applicable to Holi festival organisers too, he said.Senior counsel S Niranjan Reddy offered some suggestions based on the model followed by the UK government, which is deputing medical teams and officials to schools to educate children and teachers about Covid-19. “Instead of earmarking isolation wards in hospitals, there should be two or three hospitals that should be designated and all suspected patients should be shifted to these hospitals, because the isolation wards in these hospitals are making the whole hospital suspect,” he said.The case was posted to Thursday for further hearing.

Title: Writers are receiving love and respect but not monetarily, says Hansal Mehta
Content: Filmmaker Hansal Mehta on Wednesday said though writers and directors are given a lot of love and recognition in the film industry today it still does not translate into monetary benefits. The filmmaker said the industry has come to realise that the role of a writer is very important."We have now begun to respect writing. We have begun to understand the role of writing in films and writers are slowly beginning to become the most important people in the developing of a film or series," Mehta told .But when it comes to remuneration, Mehta said there is still a lot of "disparity"."It is happening. There is still a lot of disparity. Like the rest of the industry, this is also driven by your last successful project. But there is a lot of opportunity for genuine writers." Mehta was speaking on the sidelines of an event.When asked about the creative liberty that writers and directors can take with their films in the current scenario, Mehta said, "Unfortunately, India being a young democracy, our democratic institution have not been robust enough and because of that we have always suffered from this...""Our freedom of expression is always been subjective to the interpretation of the establishment," he added.On the work front, Mehta's next release will be Rajkummar Rao and Nushrat Bharuch-starrer 'Chhalaang'. He is also working on a web series based on 1992 Harshad Mehta scam.

Title: State stops cattle, human kill payouts sans budgeted funds
Content:
Nagpur: The finance department move to discontinue negative budgeting to pay compensation to kin of victims killed in wild animal attacks has become a cause of concern for officials.

In 2011-12, a scheme was introduced in budget distribution system (BDS), which allowed payment for cattle kills, crop damage and human kills by wild animals even if budget in the head showed zero balance.

The state government pays Rs 15 lakh compensation to kin of victims of wild animal attacks. If there is limited budget, and if funds lapsed, still there was a provision to pay money to the kin of victims, but finance department has withdrawn this facility.

The facility has been withdrawn by the Maharashtra Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government for the last month. This has led to compensation cases remaining pending. In 2019-20, the budget outlay for human and cattle kills and crop damage compensation was Rs 40 crore.

As per official figures, from April 1, 2019, to January 31, 2020, the state paid Rs 4.95 crore towards human kills, Rs 7.17 crore towards 7,698 cattle kills, and Rs 9.20 crore towards 26,416 cases of crop damage. As the scheme has been withdrawn, no compensation has been paid for cases in February.

“Delayed compensation to victims’ kin will not only create problem for forest officials, who face the music from affected villagers, but it will also increase revenge killing of wild animals, including tigers and leopards,” said senior officials.

Senior forest officials said, “This scheme has been withdrawn temporarily. Owing to increase in man-animal conflict cases, negative budgeting was needed. We have apprised forest minister Sanjay Rathod about it. We are also speaking to the finance ministry not to withdraw the scheme.”

Chandrapur and Bramhapuri in Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve (TATR) landscape are the worst man-animal affected areas. In Bramhapuri alone, 4,800 cases for crop damage, cattle kills and human deaths are pending. “We need to pay over Rs 2 crore in Bramhapuri alone,” officials said.

Title: Coronavirus effect: President, PM Narendra Modi, AmitShah to skip Holi events
Content: NEW DELHI: As the coronavirus outbreak spreads, PM Modi and top BJP functionaries, including home minister Amit Shah and party president J P Nadda, on Wednesday said they would not attend any Holi functions this year.President Ram Nath Kovind ’s office too tweeted that Rashtrapati Bhavan will not hold the traditional Holi gathering as a precautionary measure as with “alertness and safeguards, we all can help contain the outbreak of Covid-19”. Holi is on March 10.“Experts have advised to reduce mass gatherings to avoid the spread of Covid-19 novel coronavirus. Hence this year, I have decided not to participate in any ‘Holi Milan’ programme,” Modi tweeted. Nadda and Shah said they too would not participate in any Holi function. Nadda also asked all state unit chiefsto not hold Holi events.“I have decided not to participate in any Holi Milan celebration this year. I also appeal to everyone to avoid public gatherings,” tweeted Shah, whose March 15 rally has also been postponed. Law minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said he was cancelling the Holi Milan programme scheduled at Miller School in Patna. Uttar Pradesh CM Yogi Adityanath also said he would not take part in Holi in “public interest”.

Title: Bombay high court refuses to stay ED auction as Nirav Modi's son insists paintings belong to a trust
Content: MUMBAI: Granting no relief to the son of Punjab National Bank (PNB) scam accused Nirav Modi , who approached court at the “11th hour”, Bombay high court on Wednesday refused to stay an Enforcement Directorate (ED) auction of paintings belonging to Rohin Trust.The court, however, directed ED to place the auction proceeds into a separate account, and not use it for any other purpose.A bench of acting Chief Justice B P Dharmadhikari and Justice N Borkar observed, “We find that the petition doesn’t contain any averments to justify the approach to this court at the 11th hour.’’ Diamantaire Nirav Modi, facing a case under Prevention of Money Laundering Act (PMLA) for allegedly defrauding PNB of Rs 7,000 crore, was declared a fugitive economic offender last December under Fugitive Economic Offenders’ Act.His son, Rohin, petitioned HC to challenge as “illegal, arbitrary and excessive” the 2018 attachment of a triplex penthouse, Samudra Mahal, in Worli, and a September 2019 order by a special PMLA court for auction of valuable paintings belonging to the trust and lying at the penthouse. The 15 paintings include rare works by M F Husain and Manjit Bawa.He approached HC after Supreme Court was not inclined to entertain his plea last week. He challenged the constitutional validity of the newly-amended provisions of PMLA section 3, which dispenses with intent and knowledge of possession of tainted money to establish possession of proceeds of crime and enabling their attachment from hands of third parties.Rohin’s counsel Amit Desai sought a stay on the auction, arguing that the paintings belonging to the trust cannot be “proceeds of crime” and were not owned by Nirav. The paintings purchased from trust funds in 2006 cannot be proceeds of crime which allegedly took place in 2011, said his petition.ED counsel H S Venegaokar said the online auctions only for nonpaintings began on Wednesday, and paintings will be auctioned live on March 5 in Mumbai.HC observed that though he turned 18 last May, he affirmed his affidavit last month, with no attempt to justify the “late approach” to court. Rohin had affirmed his affidavit for his petition, in New York on February 26, his petition showed.Rohin contended that he resides in US and was unaware of the proposed auction till January 21, when he read news that ED had sought to auction movable assets, particularly paintings, alleging that they belong to Nirav and firms he controls. Rohin’s plea said ED never intimated him about the attachment or auction, so he never approached any court earlier.ED, represented by additional solicitor general Anil Singh, said Nirav and his wife Amy were trustees and it had only two beneficiaries, which included her (90% shares) and Rohin (10%). He opposed the plea for a stay, saying the auction was given publicity internationally too since January 2020, and Rohin could not claim ignorance now. He added that the trust was set up over 15 years ago with Rs 1,000 but within a few days had purchased Samudra Mahal for about Rs 24 crore.HC said it would hear the matter next on March 23, as the affidavit would have to be filed by ED.

Title: CBSE allows face masks, sanitizers inside exam halls
Content:
Nagpur: The CBSE has decided to allow face masks and hand sanitizers inside examination halls for the ongoing board exam, as precautionary measure for novel coronavirus.

State school education minister Varsha Gaikwad told TOI that she will meet health department officials on Thursday and take a decision on issuing similar guidelines. CBSE is extremely strict about the items students are allowed to carry inside, but in the view of the anxiety over the virus, it decided to relent.

Board secretary Anurag Tripathi issued a statement late on Wednesday evening stating that students will be allowed to carry these items inside “if they so desire”.

CBSE’s Std XII accountancy paper is scheduled to start at 10.30am on Thursday. Soon after Tripathi’s statement, CBSE’s director (academics) Joseph Emmanuel issued a detailed circular about the need for schools to create awareness about coronavirus.

The circular talked about the importance of taking simple precautions like washing hands with soap, covering face while sneezing etc. Emmanuel directed principals to “take initiatives to teach children these simple public health measures that will go a long way in preventing spread of novel coronavirus”.

Centre Point Group of schools made an early attempt to address the issue by sending a notice to all parents about precautions to be taken specifically for coronavirus. The school made it clear to parents that any student with dry cough or nasal congestion should rather stay at home.

The school also suggested that any child whose parents have been certain to specific countries must get themselves checked for the virus. Many other schools have stepped in with other measures like teachers talking to kids during their regular classes or announcements during assembly.

CBSE’s pro-activeness is being appreciated by schools who said that ‘it is better to be safe than sorry’. Pravin Tiwari, director of Central India Public School, said “This is a good decision by CBSE and will help in strengthening precautionary measures.”

Inderpreet Singh Tuli, director of Edify School, said “I am happy that CBSE has taken this decision as it will be good for students, specifically in those cities where confirmed cases have been found.”

Dr Rajiv Mohta, a senior medical practitioner and adolescent counsellor, said “This is a very good decision by CBSE because during exams, students are sitting in an enclosed place. Students should continue wearing the masks while giving the exam and ensure that it is of good medical quality.”

Title: Bid to shift focus from riots: Mamata Banerjee
Content:
West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee (File photo)

KOLKATA: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee said on Wednesday that the Centre was “playing up” the coronavirus outbreak in the country in an attempt to “divert attention from the Delhi genocide”.

“Those killed in Delhi didn’t die of a virus attack. Who has given the right to BJP to plot the genocide?” she said.

Title: Conference on Indian Ocean postponed
Content:
NEW DELHI: India on Wednesday put off the International Indian Ocean Science Conference (IIOSC)-2020 scheduled to be held from March 16 to 20 in Goa in view of the coronavirus outbreak.

India had earlier postponed the 36th edition of International Geological Congress , scheduled from March 2 to 8 in Greater Noida . The Navy on Tuesday had postponed its largest-ever multilateral ‘Milan’ exercise off the coast of Visakhapatnam scheduled from March 18.

Though the government had rescheduled the conference for November 9-14, new dates for IIOSC are yet to be finalised. The organiser of the event cited a Unesco ’s advisory saying the virus spread was a cause for major distress among conference participants.

Title: Fire in Mumbai Today: Fire breaks out in Mumbai godown, no injuries reported
Content:
Fire breaks out in a godown in Jogeshwari area of Mumbai. (ANI)

MUMBAI: A massive fire broke out in a godown in Jogeshwari area of Mumbai on Thursday. No injuries were reported.

At least seven fire tenders are present at the spot.

As per the latest reports, the fire has been brought under control and cooling operation is under way.

Title: Weather unlikely to stall spread of virus
Content:
NEW DELHI: Some experts believe that the spread of coronavirus may be slowed down under hot weather conditions , but the forecast till March 12 doesn’t throw up any relief on that front as there is no prediction of any increase in temperature in the next few days.

Though seasonal forecast of India Meteorological Department (IMD) for March-April-May talks of “warmer than normal” temperature over northwest, west, central and parts of south India, it predicts “below normal (2-5°Celsius in general) maximum day temperatures” over major parts of the Indian mainland during the March 6-12 period.

Coronavirus outbreak: Complete coverage

In its weekly update, released on February 27, the IMD had, however, predicted that while temperatures would be “above normal” (by 2-3°Celsius) on March 5 in the north and parts of south India, it would be “below normal” (3-4 degree Celsius) in the rest of the country including central and northeast India.

There is even a prediction of fairly widespread rainfall over Punjab , Haryana, Chandigarh, Delhi and UP during March 5-7 period. Most parts of central and east India (Bihar, Jharkhand , Chhattisgarh, Odisha and Gangetic West Bengal) too may have similar conditions during the period — it means there is low possibility of a rise in temperatures there in next two days. More clarity on the trajectory of temperature rise will be available in the next update on Thursday.

Title: CBSE allows masks at Board exam centres
Content: NEW DELHI: CBSE has decided to allow students and staff to use masks and sanitisers during the ongoing Classes X and XII Boards. Separately, the Centre wrote to states and the CBSE on Wednesday asking them to spread awareness among students on basic preventive measures against Covid-19.A CBSE statement said, “In view of the inquiries received, it is clarified that face masks and sanitisers may be carried by students, if they so desire, to examination centres.”

Title: Coronavirus Delhi News: Why healthcare staff can’t mask their anxiety
Content: NEW DELHI: One of the most defining moments in the fight against Covid-19 in China was the death of Dr Li Wenliang, the doctor who made the presence of the infection public, due to the same virus. Last week, his colleague, Dr Mi Wenliang, also fell prey to novel coronavirus, underlining the risks faced by healthcare workers treating infected individuals.The data shows 1,700 medical workers have been infected by Covid-19 in China and at least six have succumbed to it.Though no healthcare worker has been affected in India, the anxiety level among the staff at hospitals such as Safdarjung and Ram Manohar Lohia, where coronavirus patients are being treated, is high.Some of the doctors TOI spoke to said the lack of personal protective equipment such as masks was the trigger behind such anxieties. “Till Tuesday, there were few N95 masks for doctors at our hospital. We managed with surgical masks. When we complained to the administration, they arranged for some N95 masks and said more would be arranged in a phased manner because suppliers don’t have enough masks,” said Dr Joyutpal Biswas, general secretary of the Resident Doctors’ Association (RDA) of Safdarjung Hospital, a nodal centre for Covid-19.For now, doctors working in the casualty, respiratory medicine unit and other departments dealing with patients coming with complaints of fever, cough and breathing difficulty are getting N95 masks. “The positive, as well as suspected cases of Covid-19, are being admitted in a separate isolation ward. Doctors going there have full gear of personal protective equipment (PPE),” he added.The RDA of AIIMS has also written to the director of the hospital for appropriate and adequate protective equipment without any interruption in their supply.The World Health Organization recommends that healthcare workers, including doctors and nurses, use surgical masks to cover their mouths and noses but the US’ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has instructed them to wear N95 masks, which are thicker than the surgical masks and fit more tightly. In the US, too, masks shortage has been reported due to panic buying and hoarding.A senior doctor at RML Hospital, another nodal centre for Covid-19, said they were a little more careful than usual these days. “If a patient comes with cough, we ask them to wear masks before examining. We are wearing masks, too,” she said, adding that the risk for healthcare workers was always high in case of any disease outbreak. “We don’t have a choice. But we also know how to deal with them.”Dr Rommel Tickoo, senior consultant of internal medicine at Max Saket, said the chances of people getting seriously ill due to the virus were rare.

Title: Coronavirus in Hyderabad: Schools shut, offices evacuated, homes sanitised as #CoronaScare grips Hyd
Content:
Worried to send my kid to school because we never know who might be infected

We are scared to travel to sec’bad now since the first

was reported there

People are having to travel to the outskirts of the city to buy masks

With a 24-year-old techie becoming the first Hyderabadi to test positive, Coronavirus officially arrived in the city on Monday. And in no time, the ripple effect was felt across the two Telugu states. While two more suspected cases were reported in Hyderabad on Wednesday, another software engineer was admitted to government-run hospital in Kakinada, Andhra Pradesh with suspected symptoms of novel Coronavirus. The techie, working for a software company in Hyderabad, had reportedly returned from South Korea a week ago. After landing in Hyderabad, he reached his native village Vadapalem in East Godavari district. While the doctors said that it may take 24 to 48 hours to get the results, authorities have swung into action with a slew of precautionary measures to contain the deadly virus.Government officials in both states wasted no time to issue statements asserting that they are fully prepared to meet any eventuality, but a sense of panic has set in among the citizens. Medical stores can’t keep up with the demand for masks ; hand sanitisers are flying off the shelves; three schools in Mahendra Hills have been shut down; many offices in Building No 20 of Raheja Mindspace have been evacuated and employees have been asked to work from home. –With inputs from agenciesWe haven’t received a formal notice about the school shutting down yet but parents are worried. My child shares a classroom with 80 other kids and we never know who might be carrying the virus. I am making sure my child washes her hands before meals and carries a hand sanitiser in her bag. – Soumya Ramesh, parentSo many people I know are not willing to travel to Secunderabad anymore as the first case of Covid-19 was reported from Mahendra Hills. Though the authorities have quarantined him and he is said to be showing signs of improvement, the fear is real! — Santhosh Miryala, IT employeeThe mask that was sold for `6 last week is now sold for `16. My friends say they didn’t find any masks till they travelled a few kilometres outside the city. It is almost like there is competition for the masks now. –G Sandeep, techie

Title: Karisma Kapoor just wore the hottest printed shirt ever
Content: Bollywood actress Karisma Kapoor is painting the town red one fashionable look after the other and her fans can't have enough of her. While the Kapoor sisters are known to slay always, Karisma is slowly becoming the queen bee of fashion when it comes to Bollywood fashion.The actress was recently spotted rocking the hottest print in town, a new print called 'Puppets' and we think it's going to become the next trend in Bollywood.We are talking about designer Masaba Gupta's brand new print called 'Puppets' from the designer's latest Spring/Summer collection.Karisma sported the ‘Many Faces’ print shirt from House of Masaba. She teamed it up with loose denims, pointed heels and she looked pretty as ever.The blue-eyed beauty accessorised the look with a black bag and shades.The actress showcased a very easy-breezy airport look and we can't stop looking at her pictures.Karisma looked as soft as the summer sand and we think her look should be the ultimate airport wear inspiration.We loved Karisma's cool look, tell us how did you like it in the comment section below.

Title: After visa curbs, Agra 5-stars cancel bookings
Content:
AGRA: A day after the government announced visa curbs on travellers from Italy, Iran , South Korea and Japan , Agra five-stars have decided not to honour bookings made by tourists from these countries, reports Anuja Jaiswal.

Industry sources said the decision was also influenced by the district authorities’ decision that hotels would be sealed for a few days if any foreigner staying in such establishments tests positive for coronavirus. A hotelier said they couldn’t afford such a closure. . “We will make full refunds,” he said. Meanwhile, the Indian Association of Tour Operators has approached the UP government urging it to direct hotels to honour bookings already made.

Title: App gives refund, airline waives fee
Content:
MUMBAI: Passengers who had booked flights to destinations battling Covid-19 have complained that airlines aren’t waiving cancellation fee and agents aren’t giving change of dates. But a couple of firms have begun giving respite to flyers.

Travel app ixigo on Wednesday announced a full refund for all flight bookings concerning China, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Iran, Italy, Spain , Singapore, South Korea and Japan for travel dates up to March 31. Among airlines, British Airways has waived its change fee to allow passengers the flexibility to delay travel booked for the next two weeks.

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: DMRC to do its bit
Content:
DMRC is undertaking measures for awareness & prevention from Corona Virus. #CoronaAlert https://t.co/QdRzwxul1x — Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (@OfficialDMRC) 1583323359000

NEW DELHI : The Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC) on Wednesday announced that it would increase the frequency of cleaning its premises in view of the coronavirus cases in Delhi-NCR region. It also plans to undertake large-scale awareness campaign regarding the disease.Dos and don'ts in both English and Hindi languages regarding the virus will also be run on digital screens at major stations like Rajiv Chowk, Kashmere Gate, Central Secretariat, Chandni Chowk and New Delhi among others."In the wake of identification of few cases of coronavirus in recent days by the authorities in Delhi-NCR, Delhi Metro has decided to undertake several measures. Delhi Metro staff have been sensitised and guidelines have been circulated regarding do's and dont's to prevent the spread of coronavirus," the statement issued by DMRC reads. More than two million commuters take metro daily.

Title: After government employees, BMC staff likely to enjoy five-day week
Content: MUMBAI: Following the Maharashtra government’s decision to have a five-day week for its employees, the same will be applicable to BMC employees , most likely from this week. This comes following a preliminary nod from municipal commissioner Praveen Pardeshi, which came on Wednesday.The five-day week will not apply to those involved in proving and tackling emergency services like fire brigade, drainage operations, sewer and health services. A senior BMC official said in case of any major mishap or flood-like situation in the city, officials have to stay back in office or be on standby. “This will still be applicable and the five-day week will only be for office staff at such times who are not involved in handling emergency services,” said a official. There are over one lakh BMC employees, of which over 3,000 work at the civic headquarters.The decision to have a five-day week will also mean that civic staff will have to put in extra hours of work. Unlike now, when employees work from 10.30am-5.30pm in BMC, with a second and fourth Saturday being a holiday, now they will have to work from 9.30am-6.30pm daily, with Saturday and Sunday being holidays officially.A draft proposal was tabled before the civic chief and he sanctioned the change in employees’ timings. There were plans to reduce casual leave days of 15 that municipal employees get in a year to eight. But no decision has been taken on that yet.Members of the civic body’s Kamgar Sanghtana met Pardeshi on Wednesday, demanding that casual leave not be reduced. Sukhdev Kashid, president, Municipal Engineers’ Association, who was at the meeting, said, “The commissioner was positive about not reducing casual leave but a final decision will be taken in a few days, he informed us.”As per protocol, the proposal will now be tabled before the civic general body meeting for final approval. It is most likely that the proposal will come up for discussion and approval at Thursday’s meeting itself, said officials. “We are not expecting resistance from elected representatives over the proposal, and are hoping that it is smoothly cleared, so that the five-day week can be applicable from this week itself,” said a civic official.

Title: Samples of Indians in Iran to be collected
Content: NEW DELHI: The government will collect samples of nearly 1,500 Indians who are visiting Iran primarily for pilgrimage and these will be brought for tests at local laboratories to prevent spread of coronavirus. Sources said though there was a suggestion that testing labs for coronavirus (COVID 19) be set up in Iran, but it was found that the process may take long. “Proposal to collect and bring the samples were found more viable option,” said an official.TOI has learnt that Iran wants the Indian government to allow its national airlines to resume operation considering that many Iranians staying or visiting India are keen to return home and samples collected from Indians in Iran can also be transported in these flights.The issue came up during the meeting of the Group of Ministers on Wednesday. Officials said Indian pilgrims in Iran recently visited the holy city of Qom They said about 500 pilgrims are in Qom, and nearly 1,000 are in different parts of Iran. Officials said since those infected with communicable diseases are not allowed to travel, India will allow only those with negative report to come back though they too would be quarantined for 15 days.Union health minister Dr Harsvardhan told reporters that India is keen to set up testing lab for coronavirus in Iran. He said one scientist had already left for Iran and more will follow.

Title: Transit hubs brought under corona lens
Content:
A passenger wearing a facemask as a preventive measure against the spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus arrives ... Read More

MUMBAI: Flyers arriving even indirectly from Italy and Iran will now be screened for Covid-19 at Indian airports. Those coming directly from the two countries and from airports in East Asia are already being screened for the new coronavirus. The DGCA in its latest circular has thus extended the ambit of medical screening to passengers arriving from Italy and Iran via transit hubs, mainly Dubai , Doha and Abu Dhabi.

In a report on Tuesday, TOI had raised concerns that exempting passengers from Iran and Italy who fly into India after transit halts could pose problems as transit airports. The DGCA said in its latest circular, “Passengers (foreign and Indian) arriving directly or indirectly from China, South Korea, Japan, Iran, Italy, Hong Kong , Macau, Vietnam , Malaysia, Indonesia, Nepal, Thailand and Singapore must undergo medical screening at the port of entry.”

Title: NIV confirms that Italian’s wife has tested positive
Content: JAIPUR: The wife of the Italian novel coronavirus patient undergoing treatment in Jaipur on Wednesday became Rajasthan’s second confirmed case of Covid-19 infection after the National Institute of Virology in Pune endorsed the preliminary diagnosis.The confirmation came even as health minister Raghu Sharma said that doctors at Jaipur’s SMS Medical College and Hospital were giving the woman’s 69-year-old husband, who is on a ventilator but stable, a combination of four drugs associated with the treatment of malaria , swine flu and HIV.“In the absence of a standard drug for the novel coronavirus, doctors can only respond to symptoms. We are administering Tamiflu (Oseltamivir), which is effective in the treatment of swine flu. We are also giving the patient Chloroquine, which is used on malaria patients, and two other drugs meant for treating HIV symptoms,” Sharma said.DS Meena, the medical superintendent of SMS Hospital , told TOI that the man’s wife was “fine” and responding to treatment. “Her husband’s condition has neither improved nor deteriorated. He remains on ventilator support.”An official bulletin issued by SMS hospital mentions that Rajasthan is still waiting for the drug remdesivir to be made available for therapeutic use on coronavirus patients.

Title: Coronavirus Delhi News: CM Arvind Kejriwal sets up task force
Content:
कोरोना वायरस के खतरे को देखते हुआ एक स्टेट लेवल टास्क फ़ोर्स का गठन किया गया मुख्यमंत्री @ArvindKejriwal स्वयं क… https://t.co/9t4PwEvuWt — AAP (@AamAadmiParty) 1583321133000

NEW DELHI: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Wednesday set up a task force to tackle the spread of the novel coronavirus in the capital. The task force is chaired by the chief minister and includes top officials of all departments concerned, the municipal corporations and Delhi Police.At the first meeting on Wednesday, Kejriwal directed officials of all departments and civic bodies to ensure that measures such as surveillance and screening were implemented on a war footing.The AAP government is making elaborate arrangements to check the spread of the virus, the chief minister said after the meeting. There is no need to close schools now and such a decision may be taken later if required, he added. The government will also crack down on black-marketeering of masks.There is no need to panic, Kejriwal emphasised, but urged people to take precautions to prevent the virus from spreading. While appealing to the people of Delhi to avoid large gatherings and crowded places, he also said, "Please wash hands frequently, and avoid touching your eyes, nose, and mouth with unclean hands." The chief minister said he hoped that Delhiites would fight the coronavirus the way they fought against dengue.The municipal corporations and New Delhi Municipal Council are contacting hotels to reach all visitors from abroad and screen them, he said. Delhi government will also run an awareness campaign in all schools through the education department."We have allotted responsibilities to separate departments and officials. We have to work in an emergency mode to prevent an outbreak," Kejriwal said, adding that the government had identified 88 people who came in contact with the only Delhiite to be tested positive so far. "All of them are being screened," he added.The 19 Delhi government and six private hospitals, where adequate arrangements were made to tackle swine flu, are getting ready to handle an influx of patients. Isolation beds and isolation wards are being created to provide adequate treatment, Kejriwal said.While two labs at AIIMS and National Centre for Disease Control are already testing samples, two more facilities are being readied at Lady Hardinge and Lok Nayak hospitals, the chief minister added. "We have sufficient N95 masks and kits for distribution. Proper dissemination of information regarding the virus is also required," he said.
